subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: How strongly phonemic for how many people is theAwe/Ox distinction? To me Awe is a distinctly longer sound than the Ox Maybe you mean the Calm/On distinction.
messageBody:
How strongly phonemic for how many people is the
Awe/Ox distinction?
To me Awe is a distinctly longer sound than the Ox
 
Maybe you mean the Calm/On distinction.
That is something specific to a British Pronunciation.
Americans say Ah (calm) instead of On.
The British On sound is lower, as in the name "James Bond"
Regards, Paul V.
P.S. Perhaps you could just create an American Subset to the Read
Alphabet. That is what I tried to do with the Shaw Alphabet.
Thanx.
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
From: Tinyallen@...
Date: Mon, 19 Nov 2007 17:53:10 -0800
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order

My initial feeling is toward number 3.

QS is admittedly not a true phonetic alphabet and
already has two mergers, the stressed-unstressed pairs
Schwa and the other one. <Can't find my reference just
now . . .>

As one who merges all three of the 'problem'
letters, I lack knowledge to answer one important
question:
How strongly phonemic for how many people is the
Awe/Ox distinction?

--- Anthony Grahn <othermale@yahoo. com> wrote:
> Some choices, in reverse order of outrageousness:
> 1. re-examine the way lexical sets are assigned.
> 2. give up on an alphabetical ordering that puts all
> word of all accents together.
> 3. get rid of a letter (presumably merging Awe and
> Ox)

- Robert A. Heinlein
